newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy will make EMU 3.0 pct goal - state auditor.
newsitem.headline: Italy will make EMU 3.0 pct goal - state auditor.

text.p: Italy's state auditor said he was sure Italy would achieve by the end of this year the three percent deficit/GDP Maastricht Treaty goal for early entry to the single European currency.

"We are positive that at the end of this year we will reach three percent," Andrea Monorchio said at a conference, adding that Italy had already fulfilled two of the other parameters on inflation and interest rates.

Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government, which has already implemented 78 trillion lire of budget deficit-cutting measures to get Italy in shape for early EMU entry, sees Italy's deficit/GDP ratio falling to three percent this year from 6.7 percent in 1996.

Referring to Italy's debt/GDP ratio, Monorchio noted that while this was currently at 123 percent compared with a Maastricht target of 60 percent, the ratio had been falling since 1995 when it stood at 124.4 percent.
"Italy is at 123 percent...but this doesn't mean it cannot fully take part in monetary union," he said, adding that the Maastricht Treaty referred to a significant fall towards the 60 percent target.
"We changed course in 1995, the ratio continued to fall in 1996 and is forecast to also fall in 1997," Monorchio said. The government sees the ratio declining to 122 percent this year.
